tn.text: Paul leaves Ephesus and continues his travels.
"After the riot" or "Following the riot"
"he said goodbye"

tn.ref: had encouraged the believers very much
tn.text: "had greatly encouraged the believers" or "had said many things to encourage the believers"

tn.ref: After he had spent three months there
tn.text: "After he had stayed there three months." This speaks about time as if it were something a person could spend. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: a plot was formed against him by the Jews
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the Jews formed a plot against him" or "the Jews formed a secret plan to harm him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive|Active or Passive]])
This means only some of the Jews. AT: "by some of the Jews" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: as he was about to sail for Syria
tn.text: "as he was ready to sail for Syria"
Here the word "him" refers to Paul. (See: [[:en:bible:notes:act:20:01|20:1]])
Luke, the author of Acts, has rejoined the group. Here the words "us," "We," and "we" refer to Luke and Paul. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])
"Traveling with him"
These are names of men. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These are names of places. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
These are names of men. See how you translated these names in [[:en:bible:notes:act:19:28|19:29]].

tn.ref: these men had gone before us
tn.text: "these men had traveled ahead of us"
This refers to a time of Jewish religious feast time during the Passover season. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:act:12:03|12:3]].
Luke tells about Paul's preaching in Troas and about what happened to Eutychus.
Here the word "we" refers to Luke, Paul, and their traveling companions. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]] and [[:en:bible:notes:act:20:04|20:4-6]])
Bread was a common food during meals. Here "break bread" probably means they shared a meal. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"he continued to speak"
This may have been the third floor house.
Here the word "himself" refers to Paul. The first word "he" refers to Paul; the second word "he" refers to the young man, Eutychus. The word "him" refers to Eutychus.
This was an opening in the wall with a ledge that was wide enough on which a person could sit.
This is the name of a man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: who fell into a deep sleep
tn.text: This speaks about sleep as if it were a deep hole into which a person could fall. AT:"who slept soundly" or "who became more and more tired until finally he was sleeping soundly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: third story and was picked up dead
tn.text: When they went down to check his condition, they saw he was dead. This can be stated in active form. AT: "third story; and when they went to pick him up, they found that he was dead" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This means two floors above the ground floor. If your culture does not count the ground floor, you may state this as the "second story."
This is the end of the part of the story about Paul's preaching at Troas and about Eutychus.
Here the word "he" refers to Paul.
Bread was a common food during meals. Here "break bread" probably means they shared a meal with more kinds of food than just bread. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"he went away"

This refers to Eutychus ([[:en:bible:notes:act:20:09|20:09]]). Possible meanings are 1) he was a young man over 14 years old (UDB) or 2) he was a boy between 9 and 14 years old or 3) the word "boy" implies that he was a servant or a slave.
The writer Luke, Paul, and his other companions continue their travels; however, Paul goes separately for part of the trip.
Here the word "we" refers to Luke and those traveling with him but does not include Paul. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive|Exclusive "We"]])
The words "he," "himself," and "him" refer to Paul.

The word "ourselves" adds emphasis and separates Luke and his traveling companions from Paul, who did not travel by boat. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_rpronouns|Reflexive Pronouns]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive|Exclusive "We"]])
Assos is a town located directly below present day Behram in Turkey on the coast of the Aegean sea. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names|How to Translate Names]])
Himself is used to emphasize that this is what Paul wanted. (See [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_rpronouns|Reflexive Pronouns]])
"to travel on land"
Mitylene is a town located in present day Mitilini in Turkey on the coast of the Aegean sea. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names|How to Translate Names]])
Here the word "we" refers to Paul, the writer Luke, and those traveling with them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])
"near the island" or "across from the island"
Chios is an island off the coast of modern day Turkey in the Aegean Sea. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names|How to Translate Names]])

tn.ref: we touched at the island of Samos
tn.text: "we arrived at the island of Samos"
Samos is an island south of Chios in the Aegean Sea off the coast of modern day Turkey. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names|How to Translate Names]])
Miletus was a port city in western Asia Minor near the mouth of the Meander River. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names|How to Translate Names]])

tn.ref: For Paul had decided to sail past Ephesus
tn.text: Paul sailed south past the port city of Ephesus, further south in order to land at Miletus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names|How to Translate Names]])

tn.ref: so that he would not spend any time
tn.text: This speaks about "time" as if it were a commodity that a person could spend or use up. AT: "so that he would not have to remain for a time" or "so that he would not have a delay" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Paul calls the elders of the church of Ephesus and begins to speak to them.
Here the word "he" refers to Paul.
The word "our" refers to Paul and the elders to whom he is speaking. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])

Miletus was a port city in western Asia Minor near the mouth of the Meander River. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:act:20:15|20:15]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names|How to Translate Names]])
Here "yourselves" is used for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_rpronouns]])
Here "foot" stands for the entire person. AT: "I entered Asia" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: how I always spent my time with you
tn.text: This speaks about time as if it were something that a person could spend. AT: "how I always conducted myself when I was with you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

This speaks about something humble as if it were low to the ground. The word "mind" stands for a person's inner attitude. AT: "humility" or "humbleness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "tears" stands for feeling sad and crying. AT: "I crying as I served the Lord" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This does not mean every Jew. This lets us know who plotted.  AT: "of some of the Jews" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: You know how I did not keep back from declaring to you
tn.text: "You know how I was never silent, but I always declared to you"

tn.ref: and also going from house to house
tn.text: Paul taught people in various private homes. The words "I taught" are understood. AT: "and I also taught when I was in your homes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

tn.ref: about repentance toward God and faith in our Lord Jesus
tn.text: The abstract nouns "repentance" and "faith" can be stated as verbs. AT: "that they need to repent before God and believe in our Lord Jesus Christ" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
Here the word "I" refers to Paul.

tn.ref: bound in the Holy Spirit to Jerusalem, not knowing the things that will happen to me there
tn.text: This speaks of the Holy Spirit compelling Paul to go to Jerusalem as if the Paul were bound to the Holy Spirit like a slave. AT: "the Holy Spirit compels me to go to Jerusalem, and I do not know what will happen to me there" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: the Holy Spirit witnesses to me
tn.text: "the Holy Spirit communicates these warnings to me"
Here "chains" refers to Paul's being arrested and put in prison. AT: "people put me in prison and cause me to suffer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: so that I may finish my race and the ministry that I received from the Lord Jesus
tn.text: This speaks about Paul's "race" and "ministry" as if they are objects that Jesus gives and Paul receives. Here "race" and "ministry" mean basically the same thing. Paul repeats this for emphasis. AT: "so that I may complete the work that the Lord Jesus has commanded me to do" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
Paul speaks about completing the work that Jesus has commanded him to do as if he were running a race. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor|Metaphor]])

tn.ref: to bear witness to the gospel of the grace of God
tn.text: "to tell people the good news about God's grace." This is the ministry that Paul received from Jesus.
Paul continues to talk to the Ephesian elders. (See: [[:en:bible:notes:act:20:17|20:17]])
"And now, pay careful attention, because I know"
"I know that all of you"

tn.ref: among whom I went about preaching the kingdom
tn.text: Here "kingdom" stands for God's rule as king. AT: "to whom I preached the message about God's reign as king" or "to whom I preached about how God will show himself as king" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: will see my face no more
tn.text: The word "face" here represents Paul's physical body. AT: "will not see me anymore on this earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche|Synecdoche]])

tn.ref: I am innocent of the blood of any man
tn.text: Here "blood" stands for a person's death, which, in this case, is not physical death but spiritual death when God declares a person guilty of sin. Paul had told them God's truth. AT: "I am not responsible for anyone whom God judges guilty of sin because they did not trust in Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here this means any person whether male or female. AT: "any person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_gendernotations]])

tn.ref: For I did not keep back from declaring to you
tn.text: "For I did not keep silent and not tell you." This can be stated in positive form. AT: "For I certainly declared to you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
This word marks a statement that is said because of what was said previously. In this case, it refers back to all that Paul has said so far in his speech about his leaving them.

tn.ref: the flock of which the Holy Spirit has made you overseers. Be careful to shepherd the church of God
tn.text: Believers are likened to a "flock" of sheep here. Church leaders are entrusted by God with the care of the community of believers just as a shepherd would care for his flock of sheep and protect them from wolves. AT: "the group of believers the Holy spirit has entrusted to you. Be sure to take care of the church of God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor|Metaphor]])

tn.ref: the church of God, which he purchased with his own blood
tn.text: The shedding of the "blood" of Christ here is likened to a payment to God for our sins. AT: "the people Christ saved from their sins by shedding his blood on the cross" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor|Metaphor]])
Here "blood" stands for Christ's death. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: vicious wolves will enter in among you, and not spare the flock
tn.text: This is a picture of people who teach false doctrine and who harm the community of believers as though they were wolves that eat the sheep of the flock. AT: "many enemies will come among you and try to harm the community of believers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: in order to draw away the disciples after them
tn.text: A false teacher convincing believers to start believing his false teaching is spoken of as if he were leading sheep away from the flock to follow him. AT: "in order to convince people who are disciples of Christ to become his disciples instead" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"be on guard and remember" or "be on guard as you remember"

"be awake and alert" or "watch out" (UDB). Christian leaders being alert about anyone that may harm the community of believers is spoken of as if they were guards in an army watching out for the enemy army. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"Continue to remember" or "Do not forget"

tn.ref: for three years I did not stop instructing ... night and day
tn.text: Paul did not teach them continuously for three years, but over the space of three years. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole|Hyperbole]])
"I did not stop warning"
Here "tears" refers to Paul's crying because of the strong emotion of concern he felt while he was warning the people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: I entrust you to God and to the word of his grace
tn.text: Here "word" stands for a message. AT: "I ask God to take care of you and that he will help you to keep believing the message I spoke to you about his grace" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
to give someone else the responsibility of taking care of someone or something

tn.ref: which is able to build you up
tn.text: A person's faith becoming stronger is spoken of as if the person were a wall and someone were building him higher and stronger. AT: "which is able to make become stronger and stronger in your faith" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: and to give you the inheritance
tn.text: This speaks about the "word of his grace" as if it were God himself that would give the inheritance to believers. AT: "and God will give you the inheritance" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
The blessings that God gives believers is spoken of as if they were money or property that a child inherits from his father. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Paul finishes speaking to the elders of the church of Ephesus; he began to speak them in [[:en:bible:notes:act:20:17|20:18]].
"I did not desire someone's silver" or "I did not want for myself anyone's silver"
Clothing was considered a treasure; the more you had, the richer you were.
The word "yourselves" is used here to add emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_rpronouns|Reflexive Pronouns]])

tn.ref: these hands served my own needs
tn.text: The word "hands" here represents the entire person. AT: "I worked to earn money and pay for my own expenses" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: you should help the weak by working
tn.text: "you should work so as to have money to help people who cannot earn it for themselves"
You can state this nominal adjective as an adjective. AT: "weak persons" or "those who are weak" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_nominaladj]])
"sick"

tn.ref: the words of the Lord Jesus
tn.text: Here "words" refers to what Jesus has said. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: It is more blessed to give than to receive
tn.text: This means a person receives the favor of God and experiences more joy when he gives to other people rather than always receiving from other people.
Paul ends his time with the elders of the church of Ephesus by praying with them.
It was a common custom to kneel down while praying. It was a sign of humility before God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
"hugged him closely" or "put their arms around him"
Kissing someone on the cheek is an expression of brotherly or friendly love in the Middle East.

tn.ref: they would never see his face again
tn.text: The word "face" here represents Paul's physical body. AT: "will not see me anymore on this earth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche|Synecdoche]])
